Quoth Michael Silverstein:
  [...]
> There's no need to use private methods to test this. Assuming the code
> paths for the two constructors converge at some point immediately after
> the input String is parsed, you can test the parsing code and the date
> processing code separately.

Indeed.  But if I take the view that tests should test behaviour
rather than code, then I have to consider 'partwise constructor
fails for (2002,2,29)' and 'parsing constructor fails for
"2002-02-29"' to be separate behaviours, both deserving to be
tested.  That they almost certainly use the same code is an
implementation detail with which the tests ought not to be
concerned, and ought not to assume.

For example, if at some point in the future these constructors are
changed to use separate implementations of the constraint checks
for some reason, I'd like the tests I write now to remain valid
and complete.  If I assume the parsing constructor uses the same
code as the partwise constructor, such a change silently makes the
tests incomplete.

  [...]
> I'd also make a bunch of helper methods, such as one that takes a
> partwise date specification and an expected exception, and then
> instantiates using both constructors, asserting that both cause the
> expected exception to be thrown. That way you're not replicating a lot
> of code.

Quite.  Unless I've missed something, this is essentially the same
solution as I proposed at the end of my last post.

--
